Riyaziyyat Tədqiqat Laboratoriyasına (MR: Welcome to the Mathematics Research Laboratory (MRL). RTL is a community that strives to conduct research in the fields of mathematics, collaboration, and innovations.
Biz Riyaziyyatın elm və texnologiyadakı: We believe that mathematics is the foundation of all progress in science and technology, and we explore mathematics to find solutions to problems in algebra and number theory related to new areas of application.
Laboratoriyamız riyaziyyata marağı olan: Our laboratory was created with the intention of offering a dynamic and supportive research environment for researchers interested in mathematics, such as students, doctoral candidates, lead researchers, and guest scientists. All of these individuals will contribute to the common goal of expanding the boundaries of mathematics. Seminars, a series of seminars, and conferences are organized to facilitate interesting new ideas and connections between fields.
Biz, həmçinin akademik azadlıq və məkan: We also create academic freedom and space so that any of our researchers have the opportunity to explore topics of personal interest. We provide support for new discoveries by utilizing good financial resources for research and modern facilities.
Direktor olaraq, Belə çiçəklənən bir cəm: As the director, I am proud of such a thriving community. It truly becomes a place where the flow of ideas freely takes shape, collaborations grow, and everyone dedicates their efforts to making meaningful contributions to the field of mathematics.
Sizi tədqiqat laboratoriyamızın adından: I welcome you on behalf of our research laboratory, invite you to participate in our events, and suggest that you get in touch with us. If you are a researcher, a student, or interested in mathematics, RTL is the right place for you.
Böyük araşdırmalar aparmaq və əməkdaşlıq: Let’s continue to push boundaries in order to make great contributions to society through conducting major research and collaborating.

Riyaziyyat Tədqiqat Lab (MRL) Bakı Dövlə: The Mathematics Research Lab (MRL) is a part of the Research, Development, and Innovation Excellence Center under Baku State University (BSU). Established in 2024, the institute aims to create a dynamic mathematical environment by bringing together leading mathematicians from around the world to collaborate on cutting-edge research activities.
MRL hal-hazırda riyaziyyatın bütün sahəl: MRL is currently looking for mathematicians to join its team, which will start operating in July 2025 or earlier, across all areas of mathematics and career stages. The institute offers a unique opportunity to focus solely on research, without any mandatory teaching obligations. However, researchers may teach at the Department of Mechanics and Mathematics at BSU and supervise graduate students.
İnstitut, Doktorant tədqiqatçılar, Assis: The institute is looking for candidates for permanent and temporary positions at the levels of Doctoral Researcher, Assistant Researcher, Associate Researcher, Full Researcher, and Honorary Researcher. Candidates must demonstrate excellence in research, including significant contributions to their field and a commitment to advancing mathematical knowledge. The offered salary will be commensurate with qualifications and experience.
Azərbaycanın paytaxtı Bakı Xəzər dənizin: Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan, is a vibrant and cosmopolitan city located on the scenic shores of the Caspian Sea. Known for its blend of modernity and tradition, Baku offers rich cultural heritage, world-class cuisine, and a Mediterranean-like pleasant climate.

2024-cü ildə təsis edilmiş Riyaziyyat Tə: Established in 2024, the Mathematics Research Lab (MRL) is a leading research institute dedicated to the development of fundamental and multidisciplinary mathematical research. Our mission is to promote innovation by linking mathematics with various fields, enhance mathematical skills among researchers, and support the advancement of cutting-edge research in mathematical sciences.
Riyaziyyatın nəzəri və tətbiqi sahələrin: Promote excellence in the theoretical and applied fields of mathematics.
Riyaziyyatın digər elmi, texnoloji və mü: Support multidisciplinary collaboration that integrates mathematics with other scientific, technological, and engineering disciplines.
Azərbaycanın elmi icmasının tədqiqat pot: Enhance the research potential of Azerbaijan's scientific community and build strong connections with global research networks.
Tədqiqatçıların peşəkar inkişafına dəstə: Support the professional development of researchers and facilitate knowledge exchange through collaboration initiatives, seminars, and academic programs.
İnstitut, Azərbaycan Dövlət Neft və Səna: The institute is an integral part of the Digital Research Laboratory (DRL) under the Research, Development, and Innovation Excellence Center (TIIMM) of Azerbaijan State Oil and Industry University (ADNSU) and plays a significant role in promoting the development of the university's research and fostering international scientific collaboration.

items.title: Weekly Research Group Seminars:
items.content: Each research group at the institute organizes weekly seminars, where senior and junior researchers, postdocs, and guests present the latest developments in their work. These seminars cover a wide range of topics central to the group's focus and encourage discussion and collaboration.

items.title: Seminars for Master's Students:
items.content: These seminars help master's students continue their research work. The seminars provide an opportunity for students to present their work, receive feedback, and connect with a broader research community at the institute.

items.title: Research Seminars for Bachelor's Students:
items.content: These seminars aim to encourage and motivate undergraduate students to pursue mathematics at the graduate level. The seminars introduce students to the world of mathematical research and demonstrate the potential and impact of mathematics in their lives, thus enabling them to appreciate many opportunities specific to the subject.

items.title: Conferences:
items.content: These large events feature presentations by leading international researchers and members of the institute. Conferences provide an opportunity to discuss recent achievements in mathematics, exchange ideas, and establish contacts with foreign researchers. The institute also provides travel, accommodation, and daily allowances for key speakers.

items.title: Seminars:
items.content: Unlike conferences, seminars are smaller and more focused; they bring together 5-10 selected researchers to deeply focus on a specific mathematical area. During the typically 2-3 day period, participants not only engage in intensive collaboration but also have the opportunity to conduct practical research to address specific issues.

The institute organizes summer schools in selected modern areas of mathematics. Participants in these programs include doctoral and junior researchers. These programs often focus on a particular area of mathematics, frequently new books recently published in the field. Presentations and discussions of the chapters in the books allow for active interaction among participants.

The institute holds thematic research terms – periods dedicated to focused research on a specific topic. These terms typically bring together 5-7 researchers who will work intensively on the selected topic over a set period. Researchers can apply for participation, and selection is done through a competitive process. This provides a unique opportunity to focus deeply on a topic, collaborate, and make significant progress on important issues.

During the summer, the institute funds summer research groups where researchers collaborate on a specific mathematical area. The groups are offered office space and a monthly research stipend for the duration of the project, which usually lasts 2-3 months. These summer research groups offer an ideal environment for collaborative work, allowing participants to explore new ideas and achieve significant results in their research.

seminar_detail.student_seminar_summary_1: In this first seminar, we will discuss some frequently used proof techniques in discrete mathematics and graph theory. We will go over a few key definitions and look at theorems based on these techniques and their goal-oriented proofs. This week, we will begin with the 'Pigeonhole Principle'.
seminar_detail.arithmetic_functions_summary_1: In this second talk of the series, we will continue with some further properties of the Möbius function such as the Möbius Inversion Formula. Then we will see some other arithmetic functions such as the divisor function and the Euler totient function. If time permits, we will start considering the summatory functions of these functions and cover a technique called partial summation.
seminar_detail.arithmetic_functions_intro_summary: In this seminar series, we will introduce and cover elementary properties of commonly used arithmetic functions like the Möbius function, Euler totient function, and divisor function in number theory.
seminar_detail.cluster_algebras_summary: Cluster algebras offer a unifying framework that connects a diverse range of mathematical areas, including representation theory, string theory, Poisson geometry, integrable systems, knot theory, and combinatorics. In this talk, we will give a gentle introduction to cluster algebras, tracing their origins in representation theory and highlighting recent developments that connect cluster structures with crystal operators. Along the way, we will explore some of the rich structures and features inherent in cluster algebras.
seminar_detail.local_global_conjectures_summary: The local-global principle in modular representation theory asserts that the invariants of blocks of finite groups are determined by the invariants (of blocks) of local subgroups. There are several outstanding conjectures revolving around this principle. Alperin's block-wise weight conjecture (1987) predicts that the number of simple modules of a block is equal to the number of its weights. The finiteness conjectures of Donovan (1980) and Puig (1982) state that there are only finitely many blocks of finite groups with a given defect group, up to Morita and splendid Morita equivalence, respectively.
